guide.title: Gentoo Linux Screenshots
guide.abstract: Screenshots of Gentoo Linux in action.

chapter.title: Here they are... click for larger PNG versions!

body.p: The screenshots on this page are contributed by various Gentoo users. Information about the used themes, background images, etc. is not available through Gentoo. You will need to contact the author of the screenshot (if you can find this person) for more information.
You can always try locating the authors on our #gentoo chat channel on irc.freenode.net or through the gentoo forums.
Scott his box uses the 2.6.14-gento-r2 kernel with Gnome 2.12, showing off the Milk 2.0 theme. All icons originated from the Gentoo web site.

Richard is one of our many Gentoo users who is impressed with Gentoo's flexibility. He describes his screenshot as "pretty cool", showing mp3 player, system status information, transparent terminals and menu and a root tail of a port scan.

Wolfram is one of the Gentoo developers accountable for anti-virus stuff in Portage. His screenshot shows a gnome-2.8 configured system running firefox 1.0.2 with qute3 theme, xmms (with xawmms skin) and two terminals showing off centericq and htop.

Michael's screenshot displays Enlightenment 0.17 (prerelease 10) with some of E17's modules, such as the clock, application launcher and pager. Alongside he runs gkrellm, mozilla, evidence, xemacs-gtk, erss (for the news feeds), gaim and xmms.

Buda is one of our many, many, happy Gentoo users. He's quite new to the GNU/Linux scene but managed to read the GPL completely :) His system runs Gnome. On the screenshot you can see Gaim, XMMS with the Gentoo_Ice skin and a compilation process for OpenOffice 1.1.3.

William has been using Gentoo for 9 months after 2 years of using Mandrake. His main window manager has always been enlightenment, which you can see demonstrated on this screenshot. You'll also find a wallpaper from Cognitive Distortion and icon's downloaded from the Gentoo website.

Alex' is a fresh Gentoo user, with his first experiences dating from October 2004 when he discovered Gentoo on the DVD that accompanied his Linux Format magazine. On his screenshot you'll find KDE 3.3.1 and Eterm 0.9.2 tailing his servers' message log. You'll also find gdesklets and calender, Kopete and gkrellm on the sides of his desktop.

Eric's desktop runs XFCE4 as window manager and ROX2 for file managing and desktop icons. On the right you see anjuta editing the sourcecode of fbgrab. Also note that the XFCE4 panel has an applet that monitors the wireless connection to Eric's home network.

Joao has recently started using Linux; after 4 months of fiddling in slackware he's now a happy Gentoo'er. His screenshot shows how little changes to the theme and window environment can make a big difference.
